message.raw:
Fairly huge changes to runmanager.
(This commit affects issues #439 and #523)
Firstly, many, many functions for interacting with globals 5 files and globals themselves, and for compiling labscripts, have been split of into __init__.py. Thus they are available to ayone with the dexterity to type 'import runmanager' without any typos. Most of file_ops.py (now deleted) ended up in there too, as indicidual functions rather than a class.
The more interesting of these functions are actually pretty well documented if I do say so myself, so go and have a look. The cooler ones are at the bottom.
These functions are mainly intended for use with BLACS and  (the future program) mise, so that they may manipulate globals and make run files to their hearts content.
In particular, the compile_labscript_async() function is designed to slot right into a GUI program, running in a thread (so as not to hog the GUI mainloop) and coughing out the compilation's output into a queue-like object, such as a subproc_utils.gtk_components.OutputBox, which I just moved out of lyse so I can use one in BLACS for this very purpose. I imagine mise will use it too.
This kind of output capturing is a *vast* improvement on what runmanager was doing previously, and as a result, you'll probably see output lines coming out of runmanager actually *in order* all the time. Runmanager isn't using an OutputBox yet, but will be soon. Making it do so isn't much of a change, it's mainly just removing duplication, since the thing runmanager is using was my first attempt at OutputBox before I made it better.
Anyway, this is all possible because I now have a long running Python process in which labscript compilation occurs. It's connected to the main process over zmq sockets (abstracted away by subproc_utils, naturally). Requests for compilation are queued up and execute in the subprocess. This should be way faster than what we've been doing so far, as we don't have to start a Python interpreter for every run file. It will be interesting to see how it goes.
Also, runmanager has a new icon. Enjoy.
Oh and I got rid of some GUI duplication and some options which I'm pretty sure no-one uses (correct me if anyone actually does), that is making h5 files without compiling, or parsing globals without compiling. So now the smallest action you can do is compile. Less checkboxes.
 I also changed a couple of icons in runmanager, the 'delete group' ison is now a minus sign rather than the universal 'no' symbol.
Oh and opening runviewer from runmanager now doesn't block runmanager until you close it.
As this is a big change there may be bugs. Hopefully not many, but be alert.

BLACS: Fixed communication with analysis server. message.raw:
Changed the default location for labscript files to C:\user_scripts\labscriptlib

Changed the default location for where to save experiment h5 files.

If you are on windows, and the becnas share is mounted, it will now detect the mount point (Z:\, etc), and build up a path for the h5 file.

This will be Z:\Experiments\<lab>\<labscript>\<year>-<month>\<day>
<Lab> is determined from the control server specified in labscript. If it is localhost, it looks up the PC name and chooses either "spinor_lab" or "dual_species_lab\<krb or narb>\"
<labscript> is the python file name without the .py extension

The default location for opening and creating global h5 files is then set to Z:\Experiments\<lab>\<labscript>

If you manually set the output directory after this, it will not revert when you select a new labscript file. To make it automatically adjust again, first manually set the dir to be the correct one following Z:\Experiments\<lab>\<labscript>\<year>-<month>\<day>

It will automatically advance the <day> when it rolls past midnight.

If you set the clock back in time, it will not update the folder as it rolls onto the next day, until it reaches the point in time when you set the clock back (this is because gobject timeouts don't update relative times, and so Run Manager has queued up a gobject timeout for 1s in the future, however in changing the clock back, you have moved that point further into the future). Daylight savings adjustments do not have any affect on this, so we are fine there!

message.raw:
Wrote a function to get around some annoying behaviour:
        """A hack to allow a file which is deleted and quickly recreated to not
        be unselected by the file chooser widget. This is the case when Vim saves a file,
        so this saves Vim users from reselecting the labscript file constantly."""

message.raw:
Now compiles labscript files! Prints their output to the output box as they run, errors in red, and stops if one of them doesn't compile. If any of the things that happen when you click the go button doesn't work out, the whole thing stops and you're asked whether you want to delete the unused hdf5 files.

OK, now once I fix that bug where you can't add and remove globals without the GUI elements overlapping each other, we'll be set! (Not a hard fix, just a boring one which I left til last)

The we gotta work out the network interface with LabVIEW.
